content.title: Turner Syndrome - Vascular Manifestations
content.definition: Vascular complications associated with Turner syndrome (45,X monosomy), characterized by bicuspid aortic valve, aortic coarctation, and aortic root dilation with increased risk of dissection. Turner syndrome is one of the few genetic conditions where aortic dissection risk is significantly elevated in young women.

epidemiology.dissection_age: Mean age 30-35 years (much younger than typical)

aortic_root_dilation.challenge: Small body size confounds raw measurements
aortic_root_dilation.indexing: MUST use aortic size index (ASI = diameter/BSA)

aortic_dissection_risk_factors.risk_score: Proposed risk calculators incorporating multiple factors

surgical_indications.absolute_size: ≥4.0 cm in small patients may be significant
surgical_indications.other: Severe aortic valve disease requiring surgery

pregnancy.contraindicated: If significant aortic dilation or coarctation

body_size.solution: Always index to body surface area

learning_objectives: Recognize cardiovascular anomalies associated with Turner syndrome
Apply appropriate aortic size indexing for small patients
Identify high-risk features for aortic dissection
clinical_pearls: ALWAYS index aortic size to BSA in Turner syndrome - raw diameter underestimates risk
Turner syndrome women have 100x higher dissection risk than general population
Dissection occurs at mean age 30-35 - much younger than typical type A dissection
Pregnancy is highest risk period - thorough pre-conception evaluation is mandatory
ASI >2.5 cm/m² is the threshold for concern, not raw diameter
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Aortic size <4 cm is safe in Turner syndrome - Reality: Must index to BSA; 4 cm in small patient may be high risk
